text:
This group has been so helpful.Thank you
I see many posts about boat tours from Naples to Capri or Positano.Can any one recommend one for a day trip.Grazie Mille

Hi all! We have about 5 days on our trip slated for Florence. We are looking for recommendations on a day trip (see photo) versus over night trip to Cinque Terre. we are primarily interested in swimming andआणखी relaxing on a boat while there- any tours or ideas appreciated!
Additionally, we want to do Tuscany and/or Chianti. Again- undecided on a day trip versus staying put a day or two in either city. We are three females-mid thirties and we LOVE wine! Not set on spending any specific amount of time in Florence either- just seems like the best option for day trips.

Thank you!

comments.comment_text:
Chianti is a part of Tuscany. If you want to do wine adventures I highly recommend hiring a driver. We use

https://
www.montalcinowi
netours.com/

CT is far better as an overnight — the 3 hrs travel from Firenze each way, leaves little time for each of the 5 towns, and you'd have to coordinate that w/ specific boat times. Beach area is scarce aside from Monterosso and some rocky bits in Manarola. Swimming / boating can be combined by some of the boat tours. Nord Est of Vernazza (which is in your picture) provides boat + swim trips:

https://
www.nordest-vern
azza.it/en/
welcome/

For Chianti-region wine, "Tuscan Yes" is a great company that will pick you up in Florence and give you a wide range of wine experiences all around Tuscany. Letizia and Caterina are prompt, reliable and knowledgeable:
https://
www.tuscanyestou
r.com/
Loved Cinque Terre. I went with an injured knee. But had to see it. Loved Monterossa.
Cinque Terre is amazing. It definitely deserves more than a day trip. 😊

We spent 3 1/2 days in CT in May/June after 4 days in Florence. I wouldn’t suggest a day trip from Florence to CT, if you can-stay at least 1 night in CT but 2 or more would be better. It’s also absolutely beautiful at night when the crowds have gone back to their cruise ships or larger towns

You can easily do a day trip to tuscany and visit a winery for wine tasting and lunch and make it back to Florence for dinner time. I also did a day trip to milan just to go to QC Terme spa which is one of the top spas! I took an early train, spent time at the spa, had lunch there and came back on the last train. Highly recommend QC Terme milan!

Do not go on this day trip if you want to relax
Trust me
Cinque Terre deserves more than a day trip. Spend a few days there - you won’t regret it.
Cinque terre go for it, not one day trip more if you can
Definitely worth it. I went for the day and saw lots, of course it would be great to be able to stay a few days.

It really depends on what you want. CT is extremely overrun by tourists. To the extent that, while beautiful, there is very little authenticity left. (Locals have all but vacated the towns- especially over the last 2 years. It's my understanding that they go back to work but relatively few live there anymore.) It's basically a tourist trap. That may be fine for you & exactly what you're looking for. And that's OK. It's popular for a reason.

Chianti is in Tuscany. It will be relaxing in a different way.

CT deserves more than day trip. If you like to enjoy relaxing in the sun and ocean and swim, you need at least 3days

I was thinking day trip from Florence first but I am glad that I changed plan to stay a couple days in CT

Go to Vernazza and stay for at least one night. Book a private sunset cruise with hellocinqueterr
e and you will be able to see all the villages from the water and have time for a swim.

Toscana has a beautiful seaside too (Maremma coast i.e). It doesn’t really make sense to go to Cinque Terre from Florence for just one day.
At least you should spend 3 days at Cinque Terre and 2 in Florence.

CT deserves a minimum of 2 nights in either Riomaggiore (1st town) or Monterossa (last town). Trains are super easy between the 5 towns.

For Tuscany, you’ll need a car. Chianti is stunning and deserves a couple nights in a cute B&B to get the experience. Suggest hiring a car in Florence and going out for a couple days.

You won’t need more than 2 days in Florence.

Side note; could even do a day trip to Bologna. Food capital of the world. Worth a visit!
Stay in Lucca, you'll love it and do day trips
Vernazza is best enjoyed morning and evening when all the day trippers leave! Definitely overnight. You won’t regret it!

I did the day trip from Florence with Ciao Florence. It’s great to get a taste, we visited 4 out of 5 of the lands. Some places we had an hour or two, some we only had 30ish minutes. I was satisfied as I didn’t want to commit multiple days of my trip to Cinque Terre. I guess it just depends on what you’re looking for.
This feedback Is incredible. We will plan to stay in CT a couple of days. Any favorite hotels or air bnbs?
Meg Girard Melisande Girard

We did 2 days cinque Terre
1 San Gimignano
2 days siena
2 days Florence

We have hated Florence I would have much rather spend my Time in cinque Terre we actually stayed at Levanto amazing!!
We from from CT to Florence hence the stop overs etc

comments.comment_text:
Can you fly into Rome instead? Milan is the least Italian of Italy.
For Venice, Florence or Rome one lifetime would not be enough to see it all..but at least 3/ 4 days would work the first time

I agree with Alice, if pissible I would fly into Venice and start my tour from there, or do the reverse flying into Naples. You could also choose Rome as your base. As for hotels vs Airbnb it's up to you and your needs, look for the best prices per location.

Book tickets on line before you go its cheaper and very easy trainitalua or omio great way to get between cities and well organised. We flew to venice first time very easy to get everywhere from station and buses outside very cheal to hotel think about 2 euris i woukd do venice flirence rome sorrento naples flyy out if naples and look for hotels on booking.com or trip advusor some you can pay at the hotel so you can cancel if necessary with no hassles.have a great time

Depending on how much time you have, I would spend a day or two in Como as it’s is close to Milan.
Then allow around 4 hours travelling between each city and at least 3 full days each.
If the children are not too young they will love the high speed trains. Make sure they can handle their own luggage and keep it to one wheeled suitcase and small daypack each.
Youth hostels are relatively cheap and have family rooms. Do some research and see what they are like.
Apartments and Air BnB might suit your purposes better for things like laundry and cheaper for eating.
Give yourself time to just soak in the atmosphere. Grab a gelato and sit on some steps or a low wall somewhere.

text:
Hi everyone!
Looking for some advice. Our hotel in Venice was booked through a package where we didn’t get to choose our accommodations. It is the “Smart Hotel Holiday Venice” which is inland and Google mapsआणखी shows it to be a 40 minute to one hour journey to St Marks Square. We have tours and things planned and that is the meeting place for all of them. We expected our hotel to be close by to everything we are doing. When I called the company we booked with I was told that “anything in that area is a 10 minute drive” which makes no sense? I’ve called twice to complain and ask to be moved to a different hotel but they refuse to do anything. So - is the travelling between as bad as it looks? I’m considering just paying out of pocket for alternative accommodations that are closer.
We are going to see a few different cities during our trip but Venice is first and this whole thing is stressing me out. I don’t want to start our trip on a bad foot.
Any advice appreciated. TIA ❤️

comments.comment_text:
I suggest this one

Centro Culturale Don Orione Artigianelli
It is very well located and very clean.
I am in same situation - looks to be in same location, from what I am reading, it seems an easy and quick journey into Venice from that area..

I have found that organised tours never stay in the best places. We stayed in Mestre as part of our tour. The hotel was fine, and bus to and from Venice easy. Loved Venice, and was great to be told the history and see the main sights. Alsovisited Murano and Burano as part of tour. But we are going again in September on our own, and have booked an hotel in Venice, on a canal.
The hotel in Rome was also great, but miles from everything.
I have just realised my profile pic was actually taken in a restaurant in Burano!
We stayed in Mestre, right on the bus line. We thought it was quick and easy and affordable to get to Venice. Bus went late too, so it wasn’t a trouble to get off island late.

Hotel Bel Sito Venezia
https://
www.hotelbelsito
venezia.it/ › ... very central, reasonable, great staff and breakfast. You can walk to either end and points in between. No transit needed other than getting there once. Even if you only have one night. Nights in Venice are so different.
ihmmm… Id say thats a trekk!! but its gonna cost ya! decide whats better for you. Paying a water taxi to come in everyday or paying to stay local??
Our hotel Al Ponte Mocenigo is in San Polo area of Venice close to everything but in a quiet area. Close to a vaporetto stop.
Mestre is definitely not Venice, that why they call it Mestre. I’ve been to both and I wouldn’t stay in Mestre in a million years. Cut your losses and stay in Venice, you won’t be disappointed.

I have a hotel in the U.S. I have travel agents book our property though a package. Unfortunately the guests do not realize the whole reservation system they use is Expedia . It states right on the booking confirmation , NOT to mention “Expedia “ to the guest. It’s dishonest as far as I’m concerned.
I can’t tell you, have many European travel agents use Expedia for making reservations for their customers. You are always better off making your own reservations. They are not doing anything special for you. I’m sorry you have to deal with this while on vacation. Also one more thing to mention is we are cut out of an additional 10% of our rates with these package prices that I have to assume goes to the travel agent. 😥 my rates on Expedia are higher then other booking websites because of this practice. I lean towards Booking dot com when I travel abroad .

Thanks everyone for the info it is much appreciated! I normally would have just booked everything myself but it is my honeymoon trip and I was just wiped from wedding planning. Luckily the rest of the hotels booked look pretty central. It looks like we’re going to look for better accommodations.
I don’t want to stress about getting back and forth even though some people are saying it’s not too bad.

We originally booked a Rome , Florence , Venice tour that included hotels . We did a little research on the hotels and were ok with all but one … that one did but have an elevator and could not guarantee us a room on ground floor. We offered to pay extra for a ground floor room but they declined . So we decided to not go with that tour and booked tours and hotels ourselves and are happier that we did . We had already booked our flights so that was a non issue .

We stayed at the Hotel Palazzo Barbarigo (palazzobarbarig
o.com) and it was worth every penny!
Just a 2 minute walk to the Rialto Bridge and a 5-10 minute walk to St. Mark’s Square.

Venice is extremely expensive compared to other cities, so if you switch and book your own hotel, it’s gonna cost some $$, but worth it to salvage your plans!!
I would taxi (10mins maybe 15-20 euro) to Venice Mestre train station and catch the train to Venice Santa Lucia train station. Train ticket is about 2 euro and train ride is 11 minutes.
That’s because you’re on mainland “Venice” (Mestre) not the island. I learned to be very careful when I was looking for airbnbs in Venice! And you can’t drive on the island of venice.
Get a hotel in Verona, is half hr by train from Venice, an cost half as much.

To be honest if you stay in that area you're going to spend a lot of time getting to the places you want to see in Venice itself plus you'll miss the atmosphere of staying in the area. I feel for you, particularly as it seems the company has sort of misled you. Last year we stayed in an apartment about 5 mins walk to St Marks. It was booked through Truly Venice Apartments. I hope you can sort all this out.
you´ll miss the lovely atmosphere in Venezia in the evening when you stay in Mestre - and apart from the boring trip into town, it´s an anticlimax to go back to Mestre - it´s quite ugly!

Everyone’s different - I wouldn’t be happy staying there - the Venice moments I loved most were later in evening wandering - shops closed , alongside canals & deserted streets. If it was me I’d feel frustrated every day o had to leave , and the time of transfers etc would take away from my wandering.

Mestre is a short train ride away but do try to be closer.
We are in a nice resort and have to shuttle back and forth to St. Mark’s Square. I would have preferred something small on the main island with a kitchen and commotion from the alleys. I’m not a resort type of gal, but we made arrangements late and were using hubby’s Marriott points and have 2 children with us.
I agree with others who say to mention this in a review.
Can u not pay extra and upgrade ur accomodation
And italians 10mintes is about an hour. Everything is 10minutes in itsly

I loved this hotel, Ca Pisani in Dursaduro area. It’s gorgeous, incredible buffet breakfast included, and very near the Academia bridge and the Guggenheim gallery.
It’s your honeymoon, if you can find a lovely hotel inside Venice I would recommend splurging and staying overnight in the city.

We had a similar situation in Prague and it was a big hassle. Yes, Venice is a walking city, but you don’t want to walk that far just to get to things you want to see. Actually, it would be a train ride just to get into Venice! I would try to get something more central. Mestre is not Venice!
Was this tour Air Canada Vacations by chance?
Personally I wouldn’t stay outside of Venice when going to Venice, it’s so unique I would have been disappointed if we didn’t stay in the city itself

I’m planning my Italy trip myself- and have learned so much from reading Rick Steve’s Italy guide- and videos- he warned about not staying close enough to sites to see. Some travel companies unfortunately often put their clients too far from the action- requiring long transportation.
It’s cheaper for them and they get a kick back on doing this! I’d book something closer so you have an enjoyable experience. Do give this company a bad review!

Hi. You need to do some research, ask the hotel for the shuttle schedule, how often does the hotel shuttle run because the shuttle is 10 mins from the train station, but the tram is 25 mins. How long is the train ride and how long is the walk to meet your tour. Staying in Maestre is a savings. I was going to stay at hotel Antony and instead stayed at Hotel Le Isole near St. Marks, 1k euro for 2 nights, mid May but no trains or shuttles or trams or bridges to carry my luggage

To be honest, as a Venetian I’d be wary of any company speaking of a “10-minute drive to anywhere” when referring to Venice specifically. I hope they know that any vehicle on wheels won’t get you past Piazzale Roma. I suppose they can (sort of) get away with this on account of the fact that Venice and Mestre are, technically, a single municipality. Of course, they are very different places and realities.

Having said that, there is a tram that will get you to Piazzale Roma in a little under 30 minutes, and buses in the late evening hours. It’s doable, if a bit of a hassle, especially considering that you’ll have to get to St Mark’s Square from there. Whether you get there on foot or take the vaporetto (waterbus), it’s going to take you at least another half hour - if you walk fairly fast and know your way around.

Some of these tour companies mislead people. Same thing happened to us traveling through Italy. Most hotels were not even to close proximity as stated on the website - lost precious time and incurred extra costs for traveling.
The hotel is in Mestre, a different city. So yes, it's at least half an hour. It's way cheaper than Venice and also a lot less crowded, but it's not the most comfortable choice
Don’t stress. It will work out. But yes, I would suggest to find accommodation on the island as it will be so much easier for you , plus it is absolutely enchanting in Venice.
Thank you for sharing!!
Stayed in Maestre and took transit to Venice- it is very easy and much cheaper than Venice City
Mestre is not Venice. Totally different atmosphere..

You’d have to take the train to Venice first and then a vaporetta to St. marks. I think it will easily take that long. Tour companies book in Mestre to save money. I did it once when I was younger on a tour. It’s not impossible. Just have to plan time and make sure you make it back across.

How many nights are you staying in the hotel? Traveling back and forth from Mestre to Venice would be time consuming and frustrating one would have to work around water taxis or water vaporettos schedules or the train schedule etc. We absolutely loved staying in Venice. If you did decide to book another place I would try to stay outside of the square where it is quieter and less expensive.

I’ll remember to never use that tour group. It’s really unfair. Would it be very expensive for you to book a closer hotel? How about a car service to Venice and then all you have to do is get to St. Mark’s? I would be very stressed. I hope it works out well and that the hotels in the other cities are in reasonable areas.

Their website is sketchy. It says they have a shuttle that will get you there in 10 minutes, which isn’t possible. Maybe they mean it takes you to connecting transit?

Commuting to a vacation isn’t the best - and you’ll then be paying for transit on top of things.

I’d pus to get a refund for that portion and book your own accommodation.

https://
www.hotelholiday
venice.com/
location/
If you can afford it, I would absolutely book another hotel in Venice and leave a scathing review for the tour company after your trip is done.
That sucks. I always encourage people to avoid tours because this is not the first time I have heard something similar. So easy to do yourself nowadays. Change it if you can.

I checked the maps and seems your hotel is in Mestre. Actually should be not so bad but this specific hotel is also very far from Mestre train station. I suggest to check directly with the hotel how much can be a taxi for Venice piazzale Roma where you have to take a ferry to San Marco. Consider just the ferry is about 7€ per person per ride. If this solution is too expensive so you can book another accommodation.
Anyway if is a tour they should provide for the transportation too… or not?

Venice is like Disney world: if you decide to spend a few days there, you'll want to be as close as possible to the attractions, to be the first to ride them and stay in until you're exhausted and ready to crash in your bed. Having to drive in and out from your Orlando downtown hotel is going to spoil much of the fun
This is the exact reason why I book everything myself....you never know what you're gonna get when you go through a third party.
It doesn’t look to be too far outside with a free shuttle. Maps says 14 min drive to near the train station. Then you would have to get a water taxi or walk to St. Marks Sq.
We recently stayed in Mestre and found the city bus quite easy to navigate to get to Venice. Maybe that could be an option? Best of luck

text: If you had two nights in Rome. What would be your go to restaurants, keeping in mind that one night we have a tour at the Colosseum at 3:45 PM?? Also, keeping in mind that I have a 16-year-old that will beआणखी celebrating her 17th birthday. We want something authentic. We live in New York. Not looking for fancy or touristy. Looking for memorable.

comments.comment_text: Armando al Pantheon, Da Enzo or Roscioli
Il sorpasso
Rhinoceros
Tonnarello or Emma

Pianostrada, Rimessa Roscioli, or good value/
experience Maccheroni followed gelato at Gioliti's
Tonnarello would be our go to. Might be a bit of a wait but if you are early enough shouldn’t be long.

La Villetta dal 1940. Is in Via della Piramide Cestia near aventino.
Is authentic roman cuisine, not turistic, typical pasta dishes (carbonara, amatriciana, cacio e pepe, gricia) are a must, served in a “cofana” a very big bowl.
Also remarkable the mix appetizer in a chopping board with different kinds of cheese and cold cuts and the hot appetizer like meatball, beans with rinds and other typical roman dishes.
I'm Roman and it's one of my favorites, it's out of the tourist area, but I really like it.
If you take metro B at colosseo, is 2 stop far away (piramide) and about 300 meters walking distance.
This place is walking distance to colosseum. We had a fantastic lunch there.
Be sure to read recent reviews as a lot of places people have loved through the years, no longer have the quality food they once had.

I asked my travel agent, who has planned a trip that is unbelievable, what restaurants she recommends and that is one thing she won’t do. She said a chef that made a restaurant #1 today could leave to go to xyz tomorrow and it could be horrible next week. Basically she didn’t want to give a crappy rec. She said that’s what the concierge is for.

I ‘m from Rome,
These are the places that I recommend.
No Touristy , good quality Rimessa Roscioli
Flavio al velavevodetto (Testaccio)
Fafiunche (Monti area)
Osteria da Fortunata (Pellegrino)
Pizzeria ai Marmi Tonnarello
I had this delicious pasta with eggplant, tomatoes, and olives at Tonnarello. The church of Sta. Maria in Trastevere is just around the corner and a stunner, too.

Check Taverna Agapè and Taverna Trilussa for very good traditional food, Eggs for something traditional with a modern twist.
Also check Renato al Ghetto, Roscioli salumeria con cucina (for something on the go at lunch), Felice a Testaccio.
Stroll through the Trastevere area. Many great restaurants. Like a small town in a big city.

text:

comments.comment_text: At a certain point, taxis and Ubers can’t get into the areas where restaurants are and you still have to go down or upstairs to your restaurant.
There is no Uber in Positano
It’s so small. You can walk. Cars can’t even get into some of the roads
You still have to walk up. No cars allowed after a certain point.

I was so determined to go to Positano for a big birthday, and I was on crutches. I took all those steps up and down. In the evening, we got a recommended driver from the hotel. It is one of my favorite places in Italy and the world. I have travelled a lot, too. Go and enjoy.
Cabs in Positano are expensive
There is one road that goes through positano and then loops back around and it is very windy and difficult. I can’t see there being Uber or taxis. It’s all quite walkable.
There is a local ‘Interno Positano’ bus but you need to walk a few minutes up to the road. No Uber and taxis aren’t frequent and are expensive.
Thanks to all who were nice to give me helpful advice and to make sure I was gonna be safe.
Don't walk. It's a very narrow street with crazy drivers and scooters
If you’re struggling with an addiction to alcohol, help is just a phone call away, thanks to the 24 –hour AA hotlines.

It’s a nightmare! We were there last week and it was so hard to get around! Buses were completely full and people were queuing for hours! There were hardly any taxis and when a taxi did come they could charge a fortune and did!
Total nightmare! We ended up having to pay euro 50 to go a few km’s!!!!
Depending on where your hotel is located, there are taxis ….. ￼ enjoy your drinks, I know we di￼d ! But those stairs ugh !

There is a taxi company and you call the central number and they will send one. It can only take you so far in but it’s better than nothing. I just left today and my girls used it for night time they go 24 hrs here is the number +39 3316891999
All of the Amalfi villages are on cliffs. There was a ton of stone steps everywhere. Maybe pick a Positano restaurant about half way down??

We found the walk up the road much easier than the stairs - and it’s a very pretty walk. Just have to be aware of vehicles at all times and stay to the side of the road. It was one-way traffic where we were, so not that hard to see or hear them coming.
Taxi to closest spot and walk down much easier lol and definitely enjoy all the wine you can makes walk more enjoyable 🤣🥂

Everyone walks … yes there is taxi & car service but expensive for a short drive. We used this service for private driver up to Ravello & back and also from Naples train station to Positano and back to Naples airport
Danny Watkins
Sleep on the beach 😂

Depends where your hotel is, there r a no of good restaurants on the road along the top without going down all the stairs to the beach. This is where I have dinner. I enjoy lunch in the beach area some days. If u share your hotel with me I can give u better advice. September I will be back for 9th time. 3 weeks.

there´s not a lot of nightlife anyway - just book a nice place with a terrace overlooking the whole place and drink at home, where bed & toilet are in stumbling distance. double bonus - it´s cheaper anyway and you don´t have to face the crowds!

We stayed up in the hills of Positano for five days and came down into the main hub for dinner and drinks nightly. The city bus will bring you back up as close as you can get to your place but you may still have a few hundred steps to climb. Our bus dropped us off right outside The International, where we would have our final nightcap before our climb. Good workout so you can eat more pasta the next day 😉 Hold on to the railing - you’ll be fine 🍷

text:

We (2 ppl) went yesterday. There were only about 50 people in the prime experience line. We got to line first so we took off first. For context there were hundreds of people waiting in the non-reservation
line!

The whole area is the Vatican so not sure what you mean. We went along a hallway then the final area was the Sistine chapel.

After they release us at 0930 we decided to do breakfast before self guiding over to St. Peter’s basilica.

Our guide said normally at 0930 all the tours are “off to the races” to be first to breakfast so she got us there quickly. There was so much food we were stuffed!

We did the prime vip which was just our family of 5 with our guide. Went through the museums first starting at 7:15, then ended in Sistine Chapel which was nearly empty of people except a couple other groups. Our guide was able to talk in the Sistine Chapel and explain things, but later on they don’t allow talking in the chapel. The guide ended after the Chapel and then we went to breakfast at 9:30. After that we could go back through the museums again (now with the crowds), but we went through the Sistine Chapel again. After that we exited and went into St. Peter’s on our own.
We done the breakfast and tour. We had breakfast in the grounds of the Vatican then went thru the vatican for our guided tour. First hour or so was good but then it got very crowded.

text: It kills me that everyday you see some snarky response to a question on here. And yet if you read other comments, there are always other people providing good advice based on personal experience. This is what people are looking for. I am pretty confident anyone on facebook is aware of google. They are looking for personal experiences not rude replies.

comments.comment_text: Big big group, over half a million people, you are bound to find every sort of individual. It's the internet.
Amen
Some people really need a travel agent because they don’t want to even try to do the work. And yes, some are looking for real world advice.

It is truly distressing to see the negative unhelpful posts. Luckily the people who want to provide actual help without judgement predominate. In groups where the opposite occurred, I have left the group. Do not need that kind of negativity in my life.
Agree ,well said .
Or a snarky response to a comment - like I just experienced on a different post!
Except for the jerks who posted about how they speak Italian in Italy.
💯 and most “snarks” would not say it in person, but lots of confidence behind a screen 🙄
Love love love this!
If you don't have anything nice to say- move on!

It is really frustrating to see the sand questions over and over when a simple search of the group using the 🔍 function at the top of the page would bring up all of the most recent posts on the same subject. Would be a good idea to include a FAQ section.
Yup well said

Do you ever clicked on a profile just to see if the person being rude looks like as much of a jerk as they sound? I used to get upset by them, now they just amuse me. ￼ There are a lot of very helpful people ￼here, just scroll past the rude ones.

We are here to help, but after the 50th question about if it s doable to do Lake Como and Puglia in the same day, or coming to Italy in the middle of August expecting some peace and quiet, or eating the best lasagna in Amalfi, it does get a little depressing.
It does look like some people land in Italy not having a clue about what to expect, while just a little 5 minute research online would solve all their problems.
I have travelled to the Usa many times, and always picked my destination (whether it was NY, Tucson, Miami, Newport, etc) AFTER reading a little about it: what to see, what to eat, what the weather would be like.Easy peasy.

Ever Notice how nice & responsive people are to your face but behind the cowardly cover of FB anonymity they can be rude. I’ve learned so much from this site about Italy & where I want to go next. Also learned a bit of How Not To Be!
Exactly!
EXACTLY!!!
Amen!

Hi, I am in Italy 30 days, and on this site, same athers pages on facebook which is for tourist in Italy. I didn t found good advice for now...??? I have one for everybody here- don't came in Italy, you will be treated like numbers for rip you of. Bad service, bad hotels, food nothing special you can eat in your country bether. Try you can see same history and see lotoof stolen art... I am so disappointed and angry and I am asking myself why I came here. Bay bay Itali never more

I understand where you are coming from. However, in order to avoid snarky responses, posters might pause for 30 seconds and avoid asking a question that comes across as rude or lazy (so many in here.). Posts in the vein of “best hotels in Rome, go!,” give that impression easily so dont be surprised to be 🔥 here. At least, take a second to explain your context and phrase your question. At a minimum, show youve done some research and make it clear you are looking for personal anecdotes/
experiences.

Angela Moore 100% this! Why do people care what questions are being asked. I’ve seen people say “it’s frustrating or depressing or their lazy”.Why do they care so much, it literally has no effect on their life at all!!
There’s a scroll function for a reason🤨
Rude people just can't scroll down and always have something smart to say. It doesn't matter if it is asked a million times, no one is obliged to answer it. Someone who's willing to help will help.

I agree somewhat, however, when people ask questions that absolutely no one has the answer for, for instance, "I'm going to be in Italy (no specific place) in mid-Oct. 2024, what will the weather be like?" This is where Google comes in, you can google trends and past years to get an idea. Or they have not done any, research on the places they are interested in and ask if "Venice" or Largo Como, etc, is "WORTH IT?" Worth it in what way? Worth it to people you don't know? Worth it as far as time? Amazement? Uniqueness, a Day trip? A Week? There are instances people have to learn to read past posts or Google, and form their own conclusion.

some of us are fortunate, seasoned travelers, others may be first timers and simply overwhelmed! Even as a seasoned, experienced traveler, I may have plenty of questions that might make my next adventure better. So share the wealth, and carry on, if, as a FB group member you get frustrated at a duplicate request !!!

Sadly it’s the downside of social media and people venting their anger and it’s cathartic for them. Trick is to not take it personally. It’s about THEIR inner demons, anger, frustration about THEIR lives.

You want to always use local currency- and at an atm never use the dynamic currency conversion!

Good lord people. It simply means you pay how you normally would.

If by credit/debit, the currency conversion is done by your card issuer at time of transaction. So whatever their rate is on that day, that’s what you’ll pay.
Pay with credit card in euros always

To answer the part of your question about local currency…. In Italy, the local currency is Euros.

If you pay in cash, you’ve already paid any currency exchange costs at the time you converted your money.

If you use a credit card (and I think withdrawing cash from an atm on your debit card as well), you will often see the option to pay in local currency, or converted to the currency of your own country.

In both cases, your credit card statement will be updated in the currency of your country (euro x exchange rate + any possible exchange fees).

If you choose to pay in local currency, you are charged in euros and all that stuff happens whenever the charge lands on your statement. That could be several days after the original transaction, at whatever exchange rate is in effect on the day/time it lands.

If you choose to pay in converted currency, you are charged in your own currency, based on whatever the exchange was at the time of the transaction.

Since markets are volatile and can fluctuate many times during a day, you could be paying a higher rate for a 9am transaction versus a 6pm transaction.

Also, I’m not 100% sure on this but I think ‘pay in converted $’ may have a hidden fee built in, which makes it look like a higher exchange rate has been charged.

And lastly - Never use a credit card to withdraw cash from an ATM unless you understand …. Unlike credit card purchases where interest does not start accumulating until the statement ‘due’ date, ATM cash withdrawals by credit card are considered loans and interest starts accruing immediately.

Hope this helps.

It means it will be paid in euros, you can't pay in dollars or whatever. You usually pay for your hotel online in advance with debit or credit. It's always easiest to use your credit card as a tourist, and you can normally withdraw euros with your credit card in a reliable atm in the airport.
EUROS
You can pay by credit card or with Euros.
Local currency just means they run your card in euros. You want this. Your bank will give you a vastly better exchange rate with no commission.
Remember that over 5.000€ you CANNOT pay cash, by law. So if your hotel bill is higher, you must pay with your card
Local currency is euros
Euros - haven’t had a credit card knocked bag anywhere

Credit cards with no foreign transaction fee used for purchase and debit cards used to cash out of atm
You pay in local currency means that - in Milan you pay in euros and your credit card converts it in your bill to whatever your home currency is and if that’s not euros that’s why you want use card with no foreign transaction fee because if not then you will be charged a percentage fee depending on card how much that is
Cash or credit card

Pay by however you want. We pay by CC.

When they swipe CC they ask if you want to pay in US dollars or Euros… always choose Local currency (Euros) your bank gives you a better exchange rate than the hotel or store etc…
Just pay when you get there on your debit card
Pay for everything on your trip with your visa card
It’s the room rate + the tax, it varies.

You will be charged in Euros by the hotel. Your credit card company will convert it to your home country’s currency when it processes the transaction. You will not see your purchase in Euros on your statement. You will see the purchase in your home country’s currency. Also, depending on the credit card you use, you may be charged a foreign transaction fee by the company that issued the card. The foreign transaction fee will be shown as a separate entry on your statement.

Do not used a debit card as a credit card.
You are opening yourself up to issues.
ALWAYS choose on the credit card option to pay in LOCAL currency. It is the cheapest conversion
CC. Choose Euro for the currency choice
Just like paying resort fees and taxes in the US. We used our regular credit card in Milan. They charge an occupancy tax for each person, plus some additional fees.

text:
Guided tour Trulli di Alberobello
The UNESCO-listed town of Alberobello is famous for its unique “trulli” dwellings, fairytale-like round stone huts topped with conical roofs that are only found in this area of… आणखी Puglia. Explore the largest concentration of “trulli” with this guided tour through Alberobello’s Rione Monti historic district, home to more than 1,000 of these picturesque buildings. Learn about their history and construction, stopping to visit the Trullo Sovrano and the Church of Sant’Antonio.
Read more about Guided tour Trulli di Alberobello - https://www.viator.com/tours/Alberobello-and-Locorotondo/Tour-a-piedi-ALBEROBELLO-Visita-guidata-dei-Trulli/d28682-91060P4?pid=P00070587&mcid=42383&medium=link&medium_version=selector

NEW UPDATE!!! Omg, new update on luggage dilemma! It was a fraud number I called!! So I’m disputing the charge now with my credit card! I’ll update y’all when the adventure is over! And I’ve always prided myself on knowing when there’s a scam going on! How it happened was I googled “Delta phone number”. And the 2nd option said “Delta airlines phone number” and also said “delta.com”. Then there was a button to press to call “Delta”. But it WAS NOT Delta!! I should have just let my travel agent handle it. But I felt under the gun. Dang!!

ALSO: my luggage went all the way through. I did not have to grab it in Paris. Thank goodness. That airport was cray cray.

Here’s an update on my luggage dilemma. If you remember, when I printed my boarding passes for tomorrow’s flight I got a page that said we might have to collect our luggage in Paris and check them back in for our final destination. We’re coming from USA. Anyway, we only had an hour and 20 minute layover and I didn’t think that would work. As a side, flights were taken care of by our travel agent. So I called Delta and because of the class of service we were booked under we were, in fact, going to have to do just that! I had to pay extra to change our class of service. I had no idea that was going to happen. So the fact that some of you responded that you did or did not have to collect your luggage upon arriving at your first point in Europe……that’s why!! It’s your class of service!! I wanted to post this FYI It’s a good example for us all to remember that not everyone has the same experience in traveling and to honor different experiences instead of arguing that “but this is how it was for me so it must be that way for everybody”.

comments.comment_text: it Has nothing to do with the class service. We only have an hour and 20 minutes out of Charleston called it in to Italy and I’m questioning if we have enough time as well because we do have to get our luggage after we go through customs.￼
Exactly !
I'm curious as to the class needed to book to not encounter this issue.... important information to know.
Glad for the update. I've been wondering how this all turned out.

I had a young woman passenger going to MXP (Milan ) yesterday. She was going to a formal wedding in Italy a few hours drive from the airport and her air tag told her her luggage didn’t even make it on the flight she was taking to JFK, so she was quite upset. My advice is if you have anything you MUST have carry it on! I know she could probably find a lovely dress in Milan or elsewhere but she was so stressed and upset. 😥

If you enter Europe in a country that belongs to the EU then the airline can check your luggage to your final destination provided that country belongs to the EU.
If a non-Schengen country (UK, Ireland, Romania, Croatia, Cyprus, Bulgaria, etc) then you have to collect your luggage at your first entry into Europe.
It also depends on whether the airport has a transit area that keeps you from entering the country. If you have to go thru Customs to get to your next flight, then you have to collect/
re-check.
Returning to the US it’s always the first place you land.
It has nothing to do with class of travel.
Hope this helps.
Thank you for sharing ❤️Safe travels.
Julie Gayde Benden I’ve been to Europe (from Boston) a bunch of times and have never had to claim bags and re check them

This sounds like 2 separate airlines that your travel agent booked you on to get the cheapest price.

Not “class” like economy vs business etc…

I’ve flown economy (lowest class seat) from US to EU many times and have always had luggage checked through to final destination. Never had to pay more etc…

I really hope you ask at checkin to make sure your bags are checked through to final destination.

We booked economy class from Australia to Germany with Singapore Airlines. Layover in Singapore and Munich. We were asked by airline staff if we wanted our bags to go straight through to final destination (Hamburg). We said yes. The Munich to Hamburg flight was Lufthansa. We did not use a travel agent. All turned out perfectly. We kept en eye on our luggage on layovers with AirTags and knew when we arrived in Hamburg - they did too.

If you bought from say AA & have layover to pick up ITA for next leg…as long as u bought at same time from AA, u don’t have to recheck. I just did this in June to july

As for my experience, if you fly the same airlines/
partner alliance, you only retrieve your luggage at the final destination. For example I flew Delta from Wisconsin to Lisbon, Portugal with layover in Detroit and Paris. My flight was with Delta from Wisconsin to Paris. Paris to Lisbon was with Air France which is a Sky Team partner of Delta. My port of entry in Europe was Paris where I went thru border passport control. However my luggage was checked all the way to Lisbon. I retrieved my luggage in Lisbon.
However, while I was planning my trip I saw that easyJet from Paris to Lisbon was cheaper by 50euro. However, if I took easyJet from Paris to Lisbon, I would need to retrieve my luggage in Paris and check in again with easyJet.
What you need to find out if your planes are alliance partners wherein luggage is checked all the way to your final destination. If not, then yes you will need to retrieve your luggage.
That is why I never use a travel agent. I have more control of my itinerary if I book tickets myself.

excludes. If you still want to use an agent to book, makes notes of your research and TELL the agent exactly what you want booked and exactly what the price you are expecting to pay. This is what I do, but Im in Australia and have no idea how US travel agents work… or don’t in this case.

Flights were taken care of for you and they booked it like that ? They should’ve known better. Not a very reliable travel agent . Lucky you questioned it . It sounds like you are travelling with different airlines to your destination. By “class “they are not meaning business or economy ,they are meaning you are not flying direct to your destination with the one airline . I have to do the same on my next trip . Only difference is, I booked it myself ,and gave myself ample time to recheck my bags for the next flight .
Silver lining would be at least you can confirm your luggage arrived on the first leg and didn't get left back at point of departure. Not much consolation but I tried.

text:
Travel tip when in Rome and you are visiting popular restaurants that don't take reservations for lunch or dinner (I.e. Tonarello, Trattoria da Enzo, Piccolo Buco, Ostaria da Fortunata, etc.)

When you arrive at the restaurant and you don't see a line in front of the door don't get overlly excited thinking "Perfect Timing!".

There is always a line just look around to find where it starts. It's usually across the street. Hope this helps!

text: Please recommend a few nice (meaning good food)restaurants in Florence that have vegetarian options as 2 of the people we are going with do not eat meat or seafood. Thank you!

comments.comment_text: All the restaurants we ate at in Florence had some type of vegetarian dish. (We try to eat mainly plant-based). Just ask if the dish is vegetariano.

There are a lot of pastas that don’t have meat or fish. If not, I’ve asked for pasta with olive oil and sautéed tomatoes or order without the meat (ie: Carbonara sans meat). Most restaurants have been very accommodating.
Brac, in Santa Croce
Ribollita and pappa al pomodoro are 2 vegetarian typical dishes you can find in almost all restaurant in Firenze.
Osteria Vegetariana in Piazza del Carmine, for example.
I emailed my hotel in Florence and they provided me with a huge list of restaurants: traditional, vegetarian, sandwich, gelato, cocktail bars etc. I will add part of email for you to see

As long as they are not Vegan any sit down restaurant will have a meal or two to choose from where we ate in Florence. Most are very accommodating. We had a very picky eater that they deleted some ingredients and added others based on diet.
Ristorante Quinoa was delicious and has a beautiful courtyard. My husband is vegetarian, and this was his favourite restaurant from our trip earlier this month.
We had an amazing meal at Cuculia. It was a $$$ splurge, but so, so delicious. I'm a vegan and my vegan options were out of this world. One of the two or three best meals I've had in my lifetime.

I am vegetarian too :). I love OBICA mozarella bar, its really great: https://
www.obica.com/
restaurants/
florence (a ton of options for vegetarians) and also this place: https://
cantinetta-antin
ori.com/en/ - (they have amazing pappa al pomodoro - traditional tomato "soup" with bread and gnocci with spinach that i love!!! Also, Alla Vecchia Bettola has vegetarian tomato sauce pasta - one of the best you will find in Florence.

text:
Any experience with hotel
Albergo Cavalletto & Doge Orseolo in Venice ??

comments.comment_text:
Yes. We stayed for a few days in May this year. We had 2 single rooms. Wed booked a twin but were offered these. The rooms are quite small and room decor a little dated but the location is the best thing about this hotel.

I suspect with so much crammed on the island all hotels have smaller than usual rooms unless very high end.

It’s a 2 min walk to st Marks Square. There is a small canal inlet behind the hotel where gondolas and parked of an evening. Sitting on the small balcony and watching the gondaleres tie up or prepare for the day in the morning was wonderful.

There’s a nice bar. Lots of good places to eat very close by.

text:
Explore the traditional Tuscan town of Lucca: this lovely city will transport you back in time! Our local guide Patrizia will show you the highlights of this enchanting city. #medievalart #italytravel #italyiloveyou #virtualworld #italytrip #vacationmood #italygram #tuscany #renaissanceart #renaissancetour #tuscanylovers #tuscanytrail #VirtualTour #art #lucca #luccacity #luccaitaly #bikelovers #history #historylovers

DAY 9 - LOCOROTONDO
Did you know? Locorotondo means ‘round place’ and this small town is as delightful as its name suggests. Its round historical center is picture-perfect: small alleys and cute balconies!
Where… आणखी to stay: Pignarè Trulli...simply magical! A place for relax and discover the Itria Valley just 2 minutes away from Locorotondo and 10 minutes from Cisternino, Alberobello and Martina Franca.

text: Hi all, has any one used credit cards to get points for free flights? I have heard there are credit cards in America that you can use to spend mobey and earn points and then when your points are enough you can get free flight tickets. How does this work and is it worth to have one? I am from Australia and I am wondering if there is similar credit card in Australia? Thanks for the advice.

comments.comment_text: If available, get a card for the initial points only. After that, you're better off using cash back cards unless you use one airline all the time.
Yes all the time. Capital one and Amex have some great cards.
Also use the points for free hotel stays.

Capital One card has a great program, and many other cards offer a promotional bonus of 60k to 70k miles just by signing up and making one purchase and paying the yearly fee ~$99 USD. Some even waive the yearly fee. Just do a Google search for the cards offered by major banks/airlines.

Capital One Venture! 2x points on everything! Can use on any airline or travel related! Wait for the big sign up bonus. Been using ours and it paid for me and hubby airline tickets to Europe! Great customer service. No foreign transaction fees!
If you go online and look for the best travel cards it will show you all the options. There are many good ones

I found this to be a useful site: https://
www.pointhacks.c
om.au/
credit-cards/

We got Chase Sapphire Preferred cards. They often have sign up bonuses if you spend X amount in 3 months you get 100K airline points. My hubby & I each got one then used the cards for every day purchases for a year & when it was time to book flights we got 1st class from US to Rome for FREE. Just make sure you pay off the card every month because the interest rate is crazy high.
We have used our Nab credit card to accumulate Qantas points. Good bonus points upon signing on. Set up automatic transfer from your debit so you don’t pay interest/fees.
Absolutely! Have United Mileage Plus credit card. My accumulated mileage plus bonus for signing up has paid for our flight to Italy.
I have a butch of miles cards and for over 25 years have not paid for any long distance flight for 3 people and one or two yearly flights to Europe

Almost Al airlines have it , we have citi advantage with AA as we are based in dfw and I also have the one with delta , we got 3 one way ticket with aa to Rome for free paid few $$ for taxes less than 15 , then we fly back with delta from Bologna , at least with the card holder y also get priority group to get on flights sooner and free 1 check bags on domestic flights and some Insurrance for car rental and no international transaction fees
We have not paid for a flight in decades thanks to credit card points. We are in the US.

Worth it but know that when redeeming its much easier to buy a base ticket and use points to upgrade.

Depending on the type of base ticket there can also be an up charge. It used to be $550 to upgrade to Polaris with points to Europe.

I have a United card from Chase.
Plenty of credit cards in Australia that do this, we have an Amex platinum. Search up the cards on the Qantas website

Yes, best to get a card that earns a transferable point so that you are not tied to one hotel/airline. Chase Sapphire products earn ultimate rewards points which transfer to 12 airline and hotel partners. Good sign up bonuses and 3x points on restaurants, 2x on travel, 3x on online groceries, etc. No FTF.

I found that the annual fees on some of the cards don't make it worthwhile for me. I used the Qantas frequent flyer website to book my Emirates flights as I prefer to fly with them but I get points that I'll use for domestic travel later
Maybe you need an American bank account too.
There are many in Australia. Depends what airlines you fly the most as to which is best for you. Also ensure that the cars you are signing up for has a sign on bonus ie 100,000 Qantas points

We have Capital One. No blackout dates, no foreign transaction fees, no annual fees and we can transfer miles between cards. Can use any airline and can use points up to 90 days past our trip to pay for ALL travel expenses, not only flights.

Look up frequent flyer credit cards in Australia on google Check out the cards for bonus points to sign up but read the conditions carefully to make sure it works for you. I am on the middle of booking flights next year. Join some of the Facebook groups for frequent flyer tips. I learnt a lot there.
Yes. We are in Australia and our American Express credit cards give us double reward points. We use them on flights every year.
Only use credit cards that will give me mileage points.

Go to Point Hacks , they list all the Aussie credit cards that will give you points to get free flights. Either go Qantas (tied to Oneworld airline alliance and Woolworths spending), or Virgin (tied to Velocity and Coles spending). We haven't paid for flights in years
Aussie here, we have a business card (NAB)that collects points and we use them for flights.

Chase Sapphire is a wonderful card for miles. When I signed up it was 90K. I just signed up for Capital One and it was 75K. Chase United Business card was 150K miles. I am currently in Greece with my 2 daughters and we flew free with my miles. We come ever 2 years and only fly with miles
Follow 10xTravel Insiders group. You will learn very quickly how to band hundreds of thousands of miles and to travel for free

I have a United Chase card and for the amount of $ I spend annually, it is to totally worth it. The card has an annual fee, so you have to look at the benefits and cost of each offer and based on your spending determine if it’s worth it for you. I can see the amount of miles I have when I log into my chase account. You get a pretty substantial amount of miles when you first open the account as well.

There's Facebook groups that specializes in points and miles. I use credit cards for everything but I don't use just one single card. As an example, Chase Sapphire Preferred gives you 2x on travel, 3x in restaurants, online groceries and pharmacies and one point for everything else. Capital One Venture/
Venture X gives you 2X regardless of the transaction and Amex Gold gives 4X on groceries and restaurants. It might be cumbersome for some people to track these but it is very rewarding once you get the hang of it. I'm currently on a 5 week trip to Europe; I used points for my flight. 🙂
Check out 10x travel, they have a free course to explain it all.
We did this with a United card and got one free ticket from US to Italy.
Google is your friend. Nearly every bank has some sort of points earning credit card.
Qantas reward points

If you have a favorite airline, check to see if they offer a co-branded credit card. American Airlines, for example, offers a Citibank card that earns "miles" that can be redeemed for flights or upgrades.

Most if not all airlines have a card. If you fly one airline most often, that is the best choice as they normally pay much better than anyone else. It doesn’t work for us as we live in Tampa and we don’t have a hub airline so almost every flight is on a different airline.

text: So what do you do with leftover Euros? I really don't want to mess with ATM's, so I'd rather start with more than less. Can I sell them back to US bank I got them from? I don't think there is a return trip in our future.

comments.comment_text: 💡Sell them to a friend going to Europe at home at parity (1 for 1) to help them and to help yourself.

We keep them for the next trip especially if the exchange rate was good. In fact, we always try to come home with as much as we left with obtained through bank atm when rates are favorable as they may not be next time!!!
You can convert them back at the bank you got them from.
I save whatever I have left as little souvenirs/ memories of where I went. When my husband and I go this September I’m starting off with .80 £ from my last trip
A lot of airports have a charity collection box for left over currency.
I saved mine for the next time… only got € 500…. Used my credit card everywhere, practically.
Most places take card, Hardly a need for cash
I traded my Euro for US dollar to friends going overseas
I exchanged my pounds at a local bank, but just kept the euros. I didn't have much left anyhow. Give them to kids as souveniers.

You could also exchange it into the currency you will be travelling next if you don’t need it for something urgent. Also some places have a minimum amount they will exchange back. If it’s small amount maybe spend it all at the airport on duty free eg use all the euros and if you’re short then pay the remainder with a credit card.

Yes you can convert back. I save mine for the next trip if I have left over. My friend wanted to sell me hers when we returned from our last trip to save conversion fees. I bought them from her gladly and now we are planning a second trip. She wished she had save them lol. I spent them already 🤣😎🇮🇹

You can take them back to your bank in the US and get them changed to USD. I keep mine for future trips to Europe so I start out with some euros. If you don’t anticipate going back though, just take them to your bank. I also like to save a couple small bills and coins as souvenir reminders for myself!
I get a minimal amount of foreign currency and spend it down at the end. If there's a significant amount left you can change it at the airport. Not the ultimate rate, maybe, but so what.
I will message you my address. 😃
You could sell the Euros to a friend going to Europe - settle on a good rate for both of you

I keep mine for the next trip 😀
Keep them for next time.

text: Hello! So we’re planning a family trip to Italy, Switzerland and France for next summer. 9 people in total (3 kids aged 1 yr, 6 years and 9 yrs) and 6 adults). We aim to cover Naples, Rome, Florence, Venice, Zurich, Lucerne and Paris. Do you think it’s better to purchase the Eurail pass or is it better to purchase train tickets for each destinationआणखी separately? Also, do train tickets need to be purchased in advance or on the day of travel is fine? Last question, is there a huge difference in comfort between regular train tickets and the business class? Each stop isn’t more than 2/3 hours long so does it really matter? My biggest worry is getting on and off the trains, I hope no one gets left behind 🤦🏼‍♀️. How long do the trains stop for? Is there enough time to board/unboard with all your luggage etc when you’re travelling in such a big group? This will be our first family trip together so feeling overwhelmed! Please bear with me! 🙂🤗

comments.comment_text:
Relax. The trains stop for a few mins unlike Japan 😉 there is a guard there to make sure everyone is on the train, then he signals it's safe to depart. The difference in the two classes is the seats are 2+1 rather than 2+2 across, so you have a bit more room. Once you dont have huge luggage it will all fit OK.

I traveled for 2.5 weeks and booked my first two trains then booked 2 days in advance for the rest. Worked out fine. I didn't get the pass, I think there was not much in the difference, I just bought each ticket for each journey using Trainline app.

On one short 30 min train there was a long line at the ticket machine and I just used the app as I stood on the platform 👌

Keep an eye on ALL your luggage
I have read many have had it stolen from the train.
We didnt have any issues. Our luggage was right above our seats

On a similar itinerary as you want. We’ve trained everywhere with Eurail passes that I bought in December during a sale. You only need extra reservations with high speed trains, otherwise you can just board the train you want and your Eurail pass is your ticket (you activate it for your day of travel). We bought first class because we did 4 high speed trains. Some trains you can’t even tell what is first class - in France - but there are more seats usually in first class. We have locks in the main compartment of luggage just to make it harder for someone to mess with but there have been no issues with anything. We have the 7 travel days in 30 days pass.

You did not say how long your trip was but here are some answers to your questions.

* **Eurail pass vs. individual train tickets:** If you're planning on doing a lot of train travel, a Eurail pass can be a great way to save money. However, it's important to do the math to make sure that it's actually worth it for your specific trip. You can use the Eurail pass calculator to help you figure out if it's the right option for you.
* **Purchasing train tickets:** If you're not going to get a Eurail pass, you'll need to purchase train tickets for each destination separately. You can usually buy tickets online or at the train station, though I prefer the trainline app myself If you're traveling during peak season, it's a good idea to book your tickets in advance, especially for popular routes like Rome to Florence.
* **Comfort level:** There is a difference in comfort between regular train tickets and business class. Business class tickets usually include things like reserved seats, more legroom, and access to a lounge. If you're traveling with a large group, business class tickets can be a good way to ensure that you all have seats together and that you have enough space for your luggage.
* **Getting on and off trains:** Trains in Europe usually stop for a few minutes at each station. This should be enough time to board and disembark with your luggage, even if you're traveling in a large group. However, it's a good idea to be prepared and have your tickets and luggage ready before the train arrives.

I hope this helps!
You’re covering the same route we did but we also went to London. Individual tickets were the cheapest because the Italian trains were quite cheap. Use the Swiss Rail site to book the tickets.

text:
Thankyou for all your advice.
My family is organising a train ride from Florence to Sorrento. I have gone into the trenitalia website and it's asking to choose seats. Is standard and FrecciaFamily what I should choose. Will we be able to fit 2 hardcase suitcases.

comments.comment_text: Freccia family is a promotion for families of 2-5 with at least one minor under the age of 15
There is space for cases, just be one of the first getting onto the train. 😉
I just booked the Freccia trains for 3 trips. It was recommended highly on one of my Italy FB pages.
Make sure you can lift your suitcases above your head so you can put them in the overhead bin. And no you don’t need to choose seats. I didn’t and the app still sat us all together

There is also space between seats for cases. I think Freccia Family is like a membership thing, not available for tourists. Just go with whichever fare price you are happy with then it will show you what seats are available in those carriages. Seats are ser out as singles, doubles ( facing back if the sear in front like on a plane) or doubles separated by a table.
Also, sometimes there are "quiet cars" that discourage phone use, lively conversations, etc. - choose according to preference.

Starting to plan a trip to Italy in February. Not sure where to begin, so leaning on you all for advice! Any tips, recommendations are greatly appreciated!!

My husband and I are planning to start in Rome. We will have about 1 week in Europe, so thinking a couple days in Rome then possibly take a train from Rome to Paris and spend a few days inआणखी Paris. Has anyone done this? Was it a good plan?

What are the must-do things to see/places to eat in Rome in February? Again, no idea where to even begin with planning this amazing trip. Help!! And thanks so much for any advice/recommendations:)

comments.comment_text: If that's your plan I recommend you start surfing the net in search of travel blogs and vlogs that can give you inspiration. Scour any social for pictures and videos, keep track of them and make a list. Place those on a map using Google My Maps or Scout, so you can get a sense of How far are these things located. Look for hotels near public transport if you aren't using a private driver. Your idea is surely feasible but you will have to make choices as to what you'll be sacrificing, Rome and Paris are huge
I suggest you to take a plane from Rome to Paris. It's faster and cheaper.

We book everything ourselves! Trains from place to place, walk, bus, or use the subway if there's one in each town you'd like to see. Find hotels or vrbos/airbnbs (we did this once in the middle to do laundry so we can have greater mobility with smaller luggage) in your price range with your preferred level of amenities each place. If you don't have strong opinions about how nice things need to be, it can really be pretty affordable. Entrance fees can add up over time...pick a few things that you really care about each place that cost money to see. Maybe book a few skip line passes. These are cheaper through the website of the museum/site than through third parties, and usually have better access anyhow. There's tons of places (churches, parks, historic neighborhoods) that don't cost anything to see! Budget a few hundred extra euro each for other extra things you find to see, snacks, or if you end up at a slightly pricier restaurant on accident.

We have planned and booked all of our trips ourselves, some multi-country, a month at a time. Book a flight that works for you, then fill in the blanks. Plan where you want to go, how long you'll need in each location, then book lodging and last trains (because you can't reserve them as far out). All online at your own pace and you'll learn a lot in your research. Just be organized (I'm a retired accountant so I use spreadsheets. If you are an Apple user, Numbers has a template called Travel Planner that's a great way to start). If you have airline points or are willing to fly economy, you can do three weeks for $10K easily, with nice hotels (4-star or better). We don't spend as much on meals as some people - that could run the budget up. We don't drive in foreign countries - take the train between locations, mostly walk but occasionally take a cab if something is too far or it's late. We didn't know how to do it the first time either - but it all worked out great. You can do it!

Hi Michelle
I used booking.com to see hotels in areas we wanted to visit, then contacted the hotel directly & saved a lot of €!
We have had breakfast included in all reservations, have used bakeries for lunches & with a bit of research have found reasonably priced restaurants for dinner (except when my daughter found ones we “had” to go to 🤣). We are foodies so have eaten well.
I have not used trains in Italy, but found booking through train company in Spain rather than third party easy & much more economical. This went for tours as well. I hope you have a great holiday. You will find a wealth of information on this page & apps like booking.com, Rome 2 Rio. Some sites you do need to book in advance & would recommend this as popular places do book out. We have not used third party websites/
providers once & have been more than happy with audio guides.
We have kept it to approximately €100/day for food and snacks for 2, including some 5 ⭐️ restaurants.
Supermarkets are a saving for drinks & snacks 😃
Best wishes for a fab holiday!

Find a AAA travel agent. You don’t pay for their services. They can book flights, hotel, trains, and buses if you need them.
Large cities usually have a Hop on Hop off bus. I try to start with that the first day so I can see if there is anything I don’t know about that I want to see. Plus they do the driving. Look for deals, buy 24 hour ticket but can use it for 48 hours.
Also look to see if the city has a city pass that is good for entry into various places, it’s usually cheaper and faster(special entry line) than buying a ticket at each site.
You can also find day trips online. They provide guides, entrance tickets and you bypass the entry line.
Have a great trip!

You can travel by train and you can use the trenitalia app to book your tickets, or if you are more relax person you can by tickets directly from the train station. If you buy online tickets you don't have to validate them, if you buy the tickets directly from the station you have to validate the tickets, you will find the machines in all the stations. You can get a local train to Sorrento from Naples and a high speed train from Rome to Florence.
You need to book now. Don’t be nervous or overwhelmed - relax and enjoy yourself. Get travel insurance.

Using trains between venice, Florence and Rome very easy and relaxing. I use a spreadsheet when i plan. Dates down the first column, then I have a column which I fill in with accomadation so I know where I'm sleeping each night. I like to book accommodation close to main train stations and walk. then a column with travel arrangements, ie train 8.05, arrive florence 10.00 then a column of things I want to do. Then as I book I colour it green. For example today booked my tickets for a time for shopping mall roof top viewing of canals in venice (free), If you've got beds at night and ensure your first and last night is easy to get to airport on time the rest will flow. Good luck and enjoy the adventure of travel.

Planned all on my own for our Oct trip. We did go to AAA for help with train bookings as they use Railbookers and they handled our trains to 4 cities plus 3 transfers to hotels and airport in Venice. We chose VRBO and Airbnb - every few day stays with washing machines to do laundry (packing easy-dry clothing and clothes pins). Read Rick Steves Italy book and watched every youtube video we could find for the cities we are visiting. Booked tours through Viator. Reserve and pay later. Booked airfares for comfort which are direct flights to London on British Airway and then Vueling Air from London to Rome out of Gatwick airport. Then flying BA from Venice to London (spending 2 days there) and direct flight on BA from London to Tampa. Flights on BA are premium economy. Overnight flight so we can sleep on way to London. Have 6 hours to rest and eat in airport before we fly to Rome. Arrive in time to check into monastery and grab dinner and bed for good nights sleep before our morning tour of Vatican and Colosseum the following morning. Going to Sorrento, Cinque Terre, Florence (farmhouse stay in Tuscany) and then finish in Venice. Think our flights are running around $1900 round trip per person. Comfort is important to us and think we will have it with prem econ on long legs. Good luck!

Traveling on the train was a breeze but keep your luggage right above your seat and your purse cross body and zipped tight.

The food is fabulous and we never had a bad meal anywhere. We cooked some but in Italy it was inexpensive to eat out and added to our adventure.

Mostly

And have a terrific andventure and safe journey.

I will tell you that the prices for accommodations and airfare are significantly up since May. I used booking.com for accommodations and compared prices directly with the hotels. I knew exactly the area I wanted to be in each place. I also got a lot of information from this group and booked local tours . I used OMIO to book my trains and I also booked transfers through the hotels. It is a lot of work and the sooner you can get everything booked the better and least expensive...

First trip to Italy, I bought Rick Steve's Italy book and actually stayed in the places he listed. It was so great to have the descriptions and realistic notes he provides. Now we have the jist of Italy, and other European countries, and owe that success to his books

We had no stress. I tried to do myself but was overwhelmed.
