Get Rick steeves book. Book your flights first then your airbnbs then trains then tours. Figure out where you want to go. For a good price it’s usually best to plan a year ahead….. can you delay to October 24 or even spring 24? I started in January for September but I know I could’ve gotten better deals if I had had a year. My trip is so far about $7000 for myself and my husband 17 nights. We used travel points for the flights. Our itinerary is 4 days rome, 7 Umbria/
Tuscany, 3 Florence and 3 Venice.

I booked it all myself for me and my husband but it was a lot of work 😂 spent a lot of time reading reviews online and recommendations
in groups like this one
We didn’t drive and I would recommend not driving!!
For rome we loved Parlamento Boutique Hotel
Chelsey Kimbrough booked our trip and she’s been great. Especially with me having a million questions and changes 🤦🏻‍♀️

It took me three months to plan our three week trip. I took my time. Booked the tickets to Rome first, and then began looking into Airbnb’s which were super affordable and just wonderful! I looked for ones that were marked with Super Host and went from there. I also booked our tours in Rome through Viator, and they worked out great! The lines there are super long so pre-booking is a must. For the Vatican, I recommend buying the “before the crowds” option, it costs more but is worth every penny! Avoid the massive crowds that will ensue later where you can’t see a thing except stinky bodies and shoulders! Yikes! We rented a car (which was fantastic!)so I can’t help you with trains and such. I wish you luck and have a great time! 🌹 BTW our time was spent in the Tuscany region…we made a loop north from Rome, went as far north as Florence and came down around Assisi and back down to Rome again.
TripMasters online. You can customize everything from cities to visit to hotels to transportation.
I’ve found lots of good info in this group. I basically decided when we’re going, and what half of Italy to see and have been taking lots of notes from here

Sorry to be negative.... Ummmm, you are a bit late. All reasonably priced hotels & apartments in great locations for Oct 2023 are long gone. Can you change to 2024? Book flights a year out then decide your itinery & start booking apartments/
hotels. Good luck

Costco has a package called -Sorrento, Rome, Florence and Venice: Your Way- you can pick flights through them (or book your own)- it then includes hotels (you get to pick from a selection) and they arrange train tickets between all the cities and airport pickup and drop off for the beginning and end of your tour
We think half the fun of a trip is planning it yourself. We've gone on maybe 30 trips, all planned by ourselves including one around the world which had several days on the Trans Siberian Railway.
I like using Expedia… some others … viatour, get your guide, once in the ground omio and free now

We went with an agent at Flight Centre, he helped with marking out a calendar and working out where we wanted to go, the order, the length of time staying there, he’s booked most of the accommodation, we’d checked places and prices but he did well, we had other places where we are staying with friends, he sorted the flights and 2 of the trains… but I’ve filled up most days with things to go and see, as well as days where we just walk out the hotel door and either go left or right and see where we end up… lots of studying online, Get your Guide and Google, Trainline and the websites of some of the popular places to see…. we are doing 3 weeks in the UK and then 1 week in France and 2 weeks in Italy (Venice, Florence and Rome) and just plotting a day trip to Positano…. Already thinking we should of got another week off !! Don’t stress, even if you plan to do just do a day, each day… Good Luck and have fun… we’re in Italy in October 😊
Everett Brown some great suggestions here

We used tripmasters.com
. We had a great experience.
Just use the trains. The system is amazing n cheap. Also runs very frequently

We went thru Costco Travel....Rome,
Florence and Venice. Includes hotel...they gave us 3 options of hotels to choose from at each spot. It includes flight and train rides from each place. Also includes ride from airport to hotel and vice versa.

Best places a visited, just got back and I booked it myself! If you have a chance do París too! Funny those were exactly my faves, we visited a lot, went for 23 days and my faves in order were Venice, Paris, Sorrento, Florence and Rome!
Take a tour with A1 travel

Once you start booking use TripIt app. Everything I book I forward and they add it to my itinerary- all the details. I leave Sunday for 10 days w 20 yr old son and first time using it. I’ll let you know how it goes…🥰
We did it ourselves, first time in Europe.
Map your route book your transportation fast trains , booking.com for hotels , read get your guide & Viator for tours & activities pack your bags travel light & have a positive outlook !

It is overwhelming, but you can book yourself. First book airline tickets then decide how many days you want to stay in each location based on what you want to see. You can take a train from Florence to Venice for the day. It’s an amazing trip!

If you have never been, I suggest you get a travel agent to do it for you. The 1st time I went I did a bus tour, it gave me an overview of Europe and I learnt what places I wanted to go back to. I now use a combination of Travel agent & do some myself. Airfares I book through travel agent, much easier if things need changing whilst you are away rather.

I’m planning my trip myself, mostly because I love the lead up and anticipation. Google flights to get best fares, also capital one travel to use my points. Vrbo for accommodations.
And the trenitalia site for trains. If you are truly stressed, work with a travel agent.
Tripmasters

Just breathe. Start with your first stop. Research Airbnb (plenty left, I just did it for October & November) pick a place , and how to get to and from there. Then next place. Remember, you don’t have to do it all in one day take your time and re-search the area. ￼
I even sent questions to the Airbnb host . ￼before I booked. I downloaded the Trainline app(this app will also do intercity trains) to my phone and the ￼Omio app for trains. And the”get guide app” to look at excursion stuff. This is my first time as well.
After much research I always plan the trip on my own! Even on cruises I plan excursions on my own! You learn so much and get so much more for your travel dollars!
We booked through Costco. Everything was taken care of, including transportation to/from Airports, train tickets between cities, flights , hotels. Highly recommend !

My $20k budget was a joke .. expect to spend wayyy more. Do a lot of research on your own , know what you want - I’ve been at it for a month plus and if you hire a travel agent PLEASE make sure it’s a solid referral. There are good ones and very bad ones.. you will waste a lot of time and energy and fees if you don’t hire the right one.

I’m doing the same trip as you - but in 2024. 2 nights Venice, 3 Florence , 3 Sorrento & 3 Rome .. let me know if you need any advice ! We are almost finalized !

I just went to Venice, Florence, Sorrento and my families town. I booked it all on my own. I was overwhelmed at first but once I booked the flight everything fell into place. I found great hotels for about $200 a night. They were rated a 3 star. They were all clean and central located. I used the train to go from Venice to Florence and from Florence to Naples.
I completely understand! I felt overwhelmed too and got a travel agent referral from a friend. Best decision ever! I’m in Ohio USA,
Did it myself … easy …. All the info is on line just research each city and pick and choose

Many options. One is to contact TripMasters. Affordable trip,packages that you build yourself and they take care of all the details. The other is to do some research, decide where you want to go and plan it yourself. Between the major towns you can take a train. Very easy. Use Rome2Rio app to see train options. Look at Rick Steves tour books or videos. Very helpful
I used a travel agency so I dont have to do anything
Book with trafalgar, for first time, it’s comprehensive, takes you in front of lines for tours, so you have an idea what Italy is all about, then can go next time other places and maybe plan yourself

Take one step at a time. How many days do you have ? What do you want to do the most! Make a list of the must see things. Leave yourself time for downtown between stuff. Look at hotels in each town and go off of how many days you can afford in each place. Might have to take a place off the list to fit your budget.

I planned all of ours for the October and it was no where near $20K. I booked the flights, the VRBO and hotels and I planned the itinerary I wanted and then worked with Mena Forino with Amalfi Coast Transfers to make those plans come to life!

text: Question about night trains. I am debating about doing a Night train from Sicily to Naples (weird this ex￼cites my kids) but when I look on the site box car fits four and there’s five of us. Has anyone ever did the night trains? Can a box fit 5 and do they care if we put five in a box car? I messaged the train￼ site and have not heard back.

comments.comment_text: How about overnight ferry from Palermo to Napoli?

You can book all the berths available in a cabin and they don't care, but they don't offer anymore cabins with six berths. The only alternative I see is buying six places in two sleeper cabins that are for three maximum.

text: Has anyone gotten tickets for St Peter’s Basilica directly from their website? I don’t want to combine it with another tour and I want to be able to go up in the dome. The website shows some info but not enough to book in advance

comments.comment_text: Lynn, tickets are not required to visit St Peter’s. You can arrange a third party tour that may include Vatican museums, Sistine Chapel and St Peter’s, but you can go on your own to St Peter’s if desired

text: Anybody care to share their driving/rental car experiences in Italy? The plan would be to pick up in Venice after our stay then drive to Tuscany and ultimately drop off at FCO prior to our stay in Rome. Thanks!

comments.comment_text: It seems like everyone here says it’s terrible and that you have to take the train. However we rented a car for 14 days, picked up in Rome and dropped off in Verona toward the end of our trip, then took train to Venice. We loved it! We saw SO many things that there’s no way we would have without it. Especially in Tuscany and also up around lake Garda and Valpolicella. Loved our winery visits. I have no idea how we would have done it without the car. Plus the experience of driving was awesome. We spent a few full days just driving around aimlessly, checking things out. Cost about $500USD for the two weeks, plus fuel and tolls. Used Hertz, and it was seamless. My wife and I think it was totally worth it.

We always rent a car when we are in Italy. Never had any problems. You are much more flexible than by train. We are always looking for parking places before we get to a town not to get in trouble with ZTL.
Don’t use Italian companies. Very stressful. Try to get you to pay for damages which were already there.

Might I suggest taking a train to Chiusi and picking up a car there?You will already be in Tuscany. Get your International Drivers License from AAA (don’t forget your US driver’s license) and take full insurance. I recommend renting through AutoEurope.com.

my husband and I always drive in the smaller towns in Italy, but not the bigger cities like Milan or Rome. We have been caught out by ZTL in Bologna but haven't seen the fine yet. He doesn't find it too stressful, would plan for parking in advance if you can. We generally rent from the bigger companies like Avis or Hertz, but in our April trip we used LocAuto which was also fine. We always get an automatic but that inevitably always means for us getting a wagon which is quite big if you wind up in the smaller streets. Hope this helps good luck!
